newsitem.title: USA: Bell Atlantic to manage Iusacell.
newsitem.headline: Bell Atlantic to manage Iusacell.

text.p: Bell Atlantic Corp. will take over management of Mexican cellular phone company Grupo Iusacell SA de CV, in a deal worth at least $200 million, Bell Atlantic and Grupo Iusacell's parent company, Grupo Iusa SA de CV, announced Tuesday.

The announcement prompted a $2 rise in Iusacell stock to $9, making it the biggest percentage gainer on the New York Stock Exchange in early afternoon trading. Bell Atlantic was unchanged at $62.875 on NYSE.
The deal was signed by Bell Atlantic, which owns 42 percent of Iusacell common stock, and Mexico's Peralta family, which owns 48 percent, the companies said.

Bell Atlantic Vice Chairman Lawrence Babbio Jr. will become vice chairman of Iusacell, replacing Carlos Peralta, and Philadelphia-based Bell Atlantic will take a majority of seats on Iusacell's board. Peralta will remain on the board.
"We believe the Mexican telecommunications market presents tremendous opportunities, and this agreement demonstrates our continuing commitment to Mexico," Babbio said in a statement.
Mexico City-based Iusacell has 220,000 subscribers in Mexico, according to Bell Atlantic.

Bell Atlantic Nynex Mobile, Bell Atlantic's joint venture with Nynex Corp., has more than 4 million subscribers in the United States. Bell Atlantic also has interests in cellular phone ventures in Italy, the Czech Republic and Slovakia.

Grupo Iusa, an industrial conglomerate with interests in construction, automotive equipment and financial services, said its manufacturing portfolio was expanding rapidly and demanding significantly more time and effort.
"With competition a reality in Mexican telecommunications, we think now is the right time for our partner, Bell Atlantic, to take the lead at Grupo Iusacell," Peralta said in the statement.

The companies said the agreement would better position Iusacell for opportunities in Mexican telecommunications, including cellular and long-distance services resulting from deregulation, the opening of markets and improving economic conditions.
Under the deal, Bell Atlantic will pay $50 million and transfer certain shares in Iusacell in exchange for a controlling interest in the Peralta group's shares.
Bell Atlantic will make a $150 million loan to Iusacell which can be repaid or converted into Iusacell stock at a price of $7 per U.S. share.
Bell Atlantic and the Peralta group will also convert certain outstanding debt and provide interim funding convertible into additional Isuacell stock.

The agreement gives the Peralta group the option to sell one-third of its interest in Iusacell to Bell Atlantic at the end of each of the next three years at prices of $8.50, $9.60 and $10.70 per U.S. share, respectively.
The companies said they want to close the deal within the next 30 days. The companies need to reach a final agreement and gain the approval of Bell Atlantic's board and Iusacell's stockholders.
The deal must also be approved by Mexico's secretary of communications and transportation, the Foreign Investment Commission and other Mexican agencies.
